chapters.title: A Fatal Bloom
chapters.summary: Elara Finch attends the opening day of the Rosehaven Garden Show with her corgi, Nutmeg. The festive atmosphere is shattered when a prominent, disliked town councilman collapses and dies after smelling a prize-winning rose.
key_events: Elara and Nutmeg arrive at the show, meeting friends and local characters.
Councilman Gerald Thornbury publicly argues with several people, including the show's organizer and a rival gardener.
Thornbury admires a rare, deep-purple rose, inhales its scent deeply, and collapses.
Initial assumption is a heart attack, but Elara notices a faint, bitter almond scent on the rose petals.
Nutmeg acts strangely around the rose bush, refusing to go near it.
chapters.ending_hook: As the body is taken away, Elara spots a single, unfamiliar gardening glove tucked under the rose bush—a glove identical to her own favorite brand.

chapters.title: The Scent of Almonds
chapters.summary: Elara's suspicions are confirmed when the coroner rules Thornbury's death as poisoning by cyanide. The police, led by the skeptical but by-the-book Chief Henderson, begin questioning attendees, including Elara.
key_events: Elara researches and confirms certain rose cultivars can be used to deliver airborne toxins.
She is questioned by Chief Henderson, who notes her public feud with Thornbury over town land use.
Elara learns the rose was entered anonymously.
Nutmeg digs up a small, broken vial near the crime scene before Elara can stop her.
Elara's fingerprints are found on the vial, placed there when she took it from Nutmeg.
chapters.ending_hook: Chief Henderson returns to formally ask Elara for her gardening gloves for testing, his demeanor turning coldly suspicious.

chapters.title: A Thorny Inheritance
chapters.summary: A second death occurs—the owner of a local nursery dies after pricking her finger on a thorny bouquet delivered to her shop. The bouquet was allegedly ordered by Elara.
key_events: The victim, Marigold Lee, was Thornbury's secret business partner in a disputed land deal.
The bouquet is laced with a toxin from oleander, cleverly injected into the thorns.
The order slip shows Elara's name, but in handwriting that isn't hers.
Elara and Nutmeg investigate Marigold's nursery, finding ledgers hinting at a lucrative, secret project.
They are caught snooping by Marigold's nervous nephew, who threatens to call the police.
chapters.ending_hook: Returning home, Elara finds a single oleander leaf placed neatly on her doorstep, a clear warning.

chapters.title: Roots of Rivalry
chapters.summary: Elara digs into the connections between the victims, uncovering a decades-old rivalry between two founding families of Rosehaven over a valuable hybrid plant formula.
key_events: Elara visits the town archives with Nutmeg, learning about the Thornbury and Finch family feud (no relation to Elara).
She discovers both victims were descendants of the rival families and had recently applied for a joint patent.
Elara's own botanical expertise makes her a plausible suspect to have recreated the lost formula.
She is confronted by an angry member of the Thornbury family, accusing her of stealing research.
Nutmeg finds a hidden compartment in an old gardening book at the library, but it's empty.
chapters.ending_hook: Chief Henderson arrives with a search warrant for Elara's greenhouse, stating a witness saw her handling oleander the day before Marigold's death.

chapters.title: Framed in Ferns
chapters.summary: The police search Elara's greenhouse and find a hidden cache of poisonous plants and a notebook detailing their effects—all planted evidence.
key_events: Elara is horrified as the police 'discover' the planted evidence.
She is taken in for formal questioning but not arrested, due to lack of direct proof.
Her friends in the Rosehaven Garden Society begin to distance themselves.
Elara realizes the killer must have intimate knowledge of her greenhouse layout and habits.
She and Nutmeg secretly review her garden's visitor log and find a suspicious entry under a fake name.
chapters.ending_hook: The visitor log entry corresponds to a day her spare greenhouse key went missing—a key she finds later that night, mysteriously returned and placed on her kitchen table.

chapters.title: A Trellis of Lies
chapters.summary: Elara investigates the fake visitor, leading her to a local garden supply clerk with a grudge against Marigold Lee. The alibi seems too perfect.
key_events: The clerk, Leo, admits to visiting her greenhouse out of admiration but has a solid alibi for one murder.
Elara learns Leo is the nephew of the third founding family, the Vances, who were cheated out of the plant formula long ago.
She attends a tense Garden Society potluck, using it to observe interactions.
Nutmeg causes a diversion, knocking over a purse and revealing a receipt for the same rare rose cultivar used in the first murder.
The receipt belongs to the seemingly sweet and unassuming show organizer, Beatrice Croft.
chapters.ending_hook: Beatrice calmly explains the receipt away, but later that night, Elara sees her arguing fiercely with the town's wealthy benefactor, Arthur Vance (Leo's uncle), in a shadowy garden.

chapters.title: The Greenhouse Ghost
chapters.summary: Elara stages a fake discovery to flush out the killer, pretending to have found the missing original plant formula.
key_events: Elara spreads a rumor that she's found the 'Finch Formula' in an old diary.
She sets up a watch in her greenhouse with Nutmeg as her alert system.
Arthur Vance breaks in, not to steal the formula, but to destroy it, ranting about his family's legacy.
He is clearly angry and involved, but his physical frailty makes him an unlikely hands-on killer.
He reveals the formula was for a revolutionary, sustainable pesticide, worth a fortune.
chapters.ending_hook: As Elara confronts Vance, a figure in a gardening cloak watches from outside. A rock wrapped with a note is thrown through the glass, reading: "Stop digging, or the dog digs next."

chapters.title: Nutmeg in Peril
chapters.summary: Shaken by the direct threat to Nutmeg, Elara considers backing down, but a near-accident involving the corgi galvanizes her to end the danger.
key_events: Nutmeg almost eats a piece of tainted meat left in their backyard.
Elara realizes the killer is someone who knows Nutmeg's routines and her deep bond with the dog.
She re-examines all evidence, focusing on who had access to her gloves, key, and dog treats.
A pattern emerges: each piece of planted evidence required access to her home and deep botanical knowledge.
She narrows the list to a handful of people in the inner Garden Society circle.
chapters.ending_hook: Beatrice Croft arrives unexpectedly with a 'peace offering' of scones, showing an unusual knowledge of the specific toxin used on the meat.

chapters.title: The Poisoner's Portfolio
chapters.summary: Elara discovers Beatrice has a hidden, award-winning collection of botanical illustrations—all of poisonous plants, each depicting a recent victim.
key_events: Elara visits Beatrice under the guise of seeking gardening advice.
She is shown the beautiful but chilling portfolio; the paintings of Thornbury and Marigold are subtly titled 'Justice in Bloom.'
Beatrice reveals she is a descendant of the original formula's creator, robbed by all three families.
She speaks of the murders as 'pruning' the corrupt family tree to restore her family's honor.
Beatrice doesn't confess outright but makes it clear she knows Elara is getting close.
chapters.ending_hook: Elara leaves, certain of Beatrice's guilt but with no proof. She receives a text: an invitation to a 'final showdown' at the now-closed Garden Show pavilion at midnight.

chapters.title: Midnight in the Moon Garden
chapters.summary: Elara goes to the meeting, bringing Nutmeg and a hidden voice recorder. Beatrice lays out her meticulous plan and her reason for framing Elara.
key_events: Beatrice explains her lifelong dedication to botany was overshadowed by the greedy founding families.
She details how she engineered the deaths to look like accidents and frame Elara, whose expertise made her the perfect scapegoat.
She reveals her final target is Arthur Vance, whom she plans to make look like he killed Elara in a confrontation before committing suicide.
Beatrice produces a syringe filled with a fast-acting poison derived from monkshood.
Nutmeg barks fiercely, distracting Beatrice as Elara tries to reason with her.
chapters.ending_hook: Chief Henderson and officers emerge from the shadows—Elara had sent him her location and the recording. As Henderson steps forward, Beatrice grabs Elara and holds the syringe to her neck.

chapters.title: The Last Petal Falls
chapters.summary: A tense standoff ensues. Elara uses her knowledge of Beatrice's pride in her work to create a diversion.
key_events: Elara talks about the monkshood, praising Beatrice's choice for its potency and symbolic meaning (vengeance).
She points out a flaw in Beatrice's plan: a rare, tell-tale pollen on the first murder weapon that only grows in Beatrice's private conservatory.
Enraged and flustered, Beatrice loosens her grip to argue the botanical point.
Nutmeg, trained for agility, nips at Beatrice's ankle, causing her to stumble.
Elara wrestles the syringe away as the police rush in to subdue Beatrice.
chapters.ending_hook: Beatrice is led away, calmly telling Elara, "The soil was always poisoned. I just tended the garden." Elara holds a shaking Nutmeg, relieved but haunted.

chapters.title: A Clean Bed for Nutmeg
chapters.summary: In the aftermath, the town recovers. Elara is exonerated, and the secrets of the past are laid to rest.
key_events: Chief Henderson personally apologizes to Elara and offers her a consultant role.
The lost plant formula is found in Beatrice's studio and donated for ethical, public research.
The Garden Show is renamed in honor of the victims, with a new focus on community.
Elara hosts a tea in her now-clean greenhouse for her true friends.
Arthur Vance, grateful and remorseful, funds a new botanical wing at the library in Elara's name.
chapters.ending_hook: As Elara and Nutmeg walk through her peaceful garden at dusk, she notices a new, unknown bud forming on a previously dormant plant. She smiles, not with suspicion, but with simple curiosity for the next mystery nature has to offer.
